awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Equitable new mobility: Community-driven mechanisms for designing and evaluating personal delivery device deployments
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF S&CC planning grant contributes to the design and development of new mobility technologies that serve city residents. New mobility technologies are on the rise in cities across the US, with micromobility platforms and autonomous delivery robots occupying the sidewalks of many cities. Amid the enthusiasm around what these devices could mean for the future of transportation and the circulation of essential goods, are concerns about who stands to benefit from these technologies. This research focuses on producing a robust understanding of the unintended harms these devices may introduce and, in collaboration with community members, offer a set of potential opportunities to support resident safety and ensure broad community benefit

Pennsylvania recently passed state-wide legislation classifying personal delivery devices (PDDs) as "pedestrians," bestowing them the same legal rights as human residents. In response, Pittsburgh government officials and residents have come together as a coalition with the aim of developing municipal standards on current delivery devices to ensure continued accessibility of public space, and strategies for planning proactively for future new mobility deployments in the area. Researchers in this project have partnered with the City of Pittsburgh’s Department of Mobility and Infrastructure (DOMI) and established connections with local advocacy organizations to develop community-driven approaches to the deployment and governance of new mobility technologies. Extending methods of impact analysis and equity measures, they draw insights from the actions and perspectives of government officials and residents who are negotiating the changing shape of the city and seeking to define community-driven technology deployments. This planning grant lays the groundwork for a longer-term research with their Pittsburgh partners and other cities, by developing methods and technologies for supporting democratic processes around public PDD deployments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
New mobility technologies such as sidewalk delivery robots are being developed and deployed in an effort to help improve freight efficiency and reduce carbon emissions, while meeting people’s increasing demand for rapid and expedient delivery. But to realize the benefits of such technology, there is a need to examine how these technologies affect community well-being and quality of life, as well as to optimize device engineering for accessibility. This grant sought to examine the impacts of new mobility technologies on the communities in which they are deployed, with particular focus on identifying and avoiding potential harms and developing designs the center local community needs. Our goals for this planning grant were as follows: 

  • Generate empirical insights on the factors that promote or hinder the deployment of new mobility technologies, with particular focus on the adaptations required to make PDDs equitable in their local contexts 
  • Co-design failure analysis techniques to inform government decision-making around new mobility 
  • Develop equity metrics to evaluate deployments underway
  • Co-construct a community-centered design and development process for mobility devices 

To achieve these goals, we drew on and extended our existing partnership with the City of Pittsburgh’s Department of Mobility and Infrastructure to form collaborations with a set of diverse participants from across all regions of Pittsburgh, with a particular focus on under-resourced communities, those disconnected from reliable public transit options, residents with disabilities, and older adults. Our community-driven research approach produced a robust understanding of the unintended harms a subset of micromobility devices known as sidewalk robots introduce and, in collaboration with community members, offered a set of potential opportunities to support resident safety and ensure community benefit. Finally, we drew out insights for policymakers and designers from the novel context of publicly deployed robots, which rely on shared, municipal sidewalks to operate. 

 

Intellectual Merit 

The increasing presence of new mobility technologies across municipalities in the United States will have lasting impact on the equity and accessibility of public space, and represents a crucial environment in which to collect data that will inform the future of transit infrastructure. This project produced (1) empirical findings on the factors that promote or hinder the deployment of new mobility technologies, with particular focus on the adaptations required to make PDDs equitable in their local contexts (e.g., device design iteration, oversight), (2) co-designed failure analysis techniques (e.g., games, simulation) to inform government decision-making around new mobility (e.g., procurement and regulation), (3) equity metrics to evaluate deployments underway, and (4) a community-centered design and development process for mobility devices. 

 

Broader Impacts 

Autonomous delivery robots are poised to disproportionately impact elderly residents and those with mobility impairments, who are often not included in their design and deployment. This project produced insights around publicly deployed PPDs, with the intent of enhancing new mobility planning by brokering public conversations around safer community-centered deployments and equitable distribution of benefits. Broader impacts of this research include a workshop series which facilitated community-based discussions and activities. This work also involved translating research insights for consumption by multiple stakeholders—including community groups, industry practitioners, and local government officials—on recognizing the unanticipated consequences of public deployments and enhancing equity.
